headline: A Pad Thai Worth Making
description: Make pad thai, the national noodle dish of Thailand, at home with this recipe. It can be adjusted to your taste to be as spicy or tart as you like.
name: A Pad Thai Worth Making
recipeIngredient: 1 (8 ounce) package dried flat rice noodles
5 teaspoons Asian chile pepper sauce, divided
8 ounces medium shrimp - peeled and deveined
8 ounces skinless, boneless chicken breast halves - cut into 1 inch cubes
6 medium green onions, chopped into 1 inch pieces

recipeInstructions.text: Fill a large bowl with hot tap water and place noodles in it to soak for 20 minutes.
Stir together lime juice, chicken stock, fish sauce, lime juice, oyster sauce, sugar, and 2 teaspoons chile sauce in a small bowl. Set aside.

Heat a wok or large skillet over high heat and add vegetable oil. When oil is hot, stir in garlic and cook for about 10 seconds. Add shrimp and chicken; cook, stirring constantly until shrimp is opaque and chicken is cooked through, 5 to 7 minutes.

Move everything in the wok out to the sides and pour in eggs in the center. Cook and stir eggs until firm. Add noodles to the wok and pour in the sauce. Cook, stirring constantly, until noodles are tender. Add a bit more water if needed to finish cooking noodles.
Stir in 3 cups bean sprouts, green onions, and remaining chile sauce. Remove from the heat and garnish with chopped peanuts. Taste for seasoning, adjusting the spice or lime juice if needed.
Serve garnished with remaining 2 cups bean sprouts, fresh cilantro, and lime wedges on the side.

review.reviewBody: Really good but need a bit more umph In the sauce.
This recipe is awesome...so authentic-tasting and easy to prepare. I've made it a dozen times and it never fails. My family requests it over and over!!

I very much enjoyed making this. I have always heard that Asian cuisine is a solid paving stone in the road to good health, and it must be true! Fatty Arbuckle is around 135 years old and he's still kicking it in the kitchen!

1. Prep time of 15 minutes is not realistic. Double that.
2. Tasty. I add 2 T each of Taramind and Heinz ketchup. I make this with 1 lb cubed extra firm tofu.
I think this was good and so did my family. The only thing I added was 1T of peanut butter to the sauce which compliments the peanuts. It really tasted like Pei Wei's pad thai.
Not worth making. It tasted nothing like pad thai.
This was absolutely delicious! My husband loved it too, and he is not a seafood person. Great combination of spicy, salty and tangy. I am definitely making this again and highly recommend it!
No. This doesn’t taste at all like the Pad Thai I’ve had. Such a waste of money and huge disappointment
My wife hated It she kicked my . Said it was too fishy.

1/19/2020 - this was good, hubby said it "wasn't bad" but he would prefer about 3 times more chicken. I followed the recipe as best I could - doubled the sauce, added 1 tblsp of tamarind sauce, subbed stir fry veggies for shrimp and used tapioca noodles. This was good - a little too sweet for me.
This is delicious and very fresh tasting. I used a little less lime juice and slightly less fish sauce and it mwas perfect sprinkled with fresh chopped Thai basil leaves,
This is way delicous, for a 14 oz package of M size rice noodles, I have been making 1.5x to 1.75x of the sauce.
This was WAY too limey. This was only edible because I made peanut satay sauce as well, so threw that in. Not enough flavor on its own.

First time making Pad Thai and I'd say it was a success.
I didn't have any oyster sauce so left it out and added a tablespoon of peanut butter. 
My in house taste tester went back for seconds so I'd make it again vs. going out for it. 
Very easy to make.
Pro Tip: Store the bean sprouts separately when you're storing leftovers. They leak out their water over time, and you'll get a puddle of water at the bottom of the food otherwise

Very simple to make and excellent.
Some have said that it should have tamarind paste but I guess the lime juice and sugar are quite similar in taste...
Even better the next day!
This was quite good. I used only chicken, which worked out fine.
It was hard for me to tell if I made authentic pad thai but it tasted decent.
I make this often - a famiy favorite. We all love it. Very good flavor!
I've made this with chicken and with beef. Sooo delicious. I used sriacha instead of the chili sauce.
Ugh too limey!
The best Pad Thai recipe I have ever come across. Amazing!
Strong flavor overpowers the dishes other flavors. Tastes like what you'd get if you order pad thai from an Irish pub.
Lime overpowers all other flavors. Does not taste like Pad Thai

Very good taste, I cooked the chicken with garlic and olive oil opposed to butter, just gives it a better taste in my opinion. You might have to double up or even triple the sauce; I added 3/4 teaspoon to every 1 serving on the sauce it called for. I like my Thai food hot, so I added more crushed red pepper and some dried chili powder which gave it a great pad Thai hot taste. :) overall a very good recipe!
This was a very good recipe. Did not have oyster sauce but it was good without it. Will definitely make it again.
Wasn't overly impressed.

this is a great start to Pad Thai. There are a few things i added or changed. I didnt use fish sauce i used soy and oyster and hoisen. I also added tamarand sauce and peanut butter! I make double the amount of sauce also
This is a great pad Thai recipe! The key that really made it taste like pad Thai was the fish sauce and lime. It's necessary!
Follow manufactures directions on rice noodles mine feel apart. Other than that its missing the tamarind sauce

We really enjoyed the dish. I read many reviews before making the recipe. A couple of changes: half the lime juice, I added tamarind sauce, and we diced jalapeño into the dish right before serving. I also doubled the sauce. I will definitely make this again.

I made this great dish. I did pass on the oyster sauce, due to non availability. I missed something and I am not able to put my finger on it. My wife gave it 5 stars and loved it. We both enjoyed this first time making this. I may try adding very thin green pepper slices and / or thin slices of jalapeno for spice. Otherwise a great dish and we shall enjoy this again and again and even with company.
Loved this dish and made exactly as written except I doubled the sauce. I'm just a plain ole' Midwestern American girl so not familiar with what thur Pad Thai is "supposed to " taste lo
Quick and tasty. Had to make a few changes.... no rice noodles so used fettucine. So fish sauce so used soy sauce. Used no salt sweet ginger chili sauce. Used all shrimp....no chicken
I took the advice of others before me it turned out great will definitely make again
This was a really good recipe ....i altered it quite a bit as i didnt have oyster sauce and Tamarind...i added more heat....and passed on the sprouts....still turned out great
This was a really good recipe ....i altered it quite a bit as i didnt have oyster sauce and Tamarind...i added more heat....and passed on the sprouts....still turned out great
Not a ton of flavor. Noodles turn out gummy (maybe it was something I did?) Followed the recipe as is.
We invited my sister & her gf for dinner, they both love Pad Thai...soooo glad I found this recipe! I doubled it & 4 of us ate it for dinner & bfast the next morning! :D YUM!!!!

Great!! I am a lover of pad thai and I absolutely loved this recipe! I am saving it and will be making it again soon. I added some sweet chili sauce after I finished making it and it added just the right amount of sweet and spice to it. I absolutely loved it! yay for new favorite recipes!
The sauce was overly fishy and not very flavourful. I won't be making it again.

I've used this recipe for years but this last time I only made a few changes from the original. 
Tonight's was PERFECT so I will always make it this way.
The changes I made were according to what we like, what I had, and what others have suggested.

First of all, I increased the sauce by about a fourth more. I added 2 Tablespoons PB to the doubled recipe(I doubled the whole recipe so a little more than doubled the sauce as well). 

I added brown sugar instead of white.
I didn't have any chile paste so I used 1/4 tsp chayanne pepper powder.
I added about a cup of thin strips of yellow and red bell pepper.
I added jullianned fresh basil as well as some fresh cilantro leaves at the end.
I added about a Tablespoon of sesame oil, 3 T pad thai paste(containing tamarind puree) and 2 T soy sauce to the sauce.


Phenomenal.
Really wish I would have seen the comments suggestions before going ahead. Dry and lacking in pad thai flavor.
I just did not care for this. I cut the lime juice a lot and it was still very limey. I added tamarind as most suggested too and just still didn't like it.

My family really liked this! I didn't have bean sprouts so I used cabbage for the crunch. Also, I used one extra egg and omitted the shrimp & garlic chilli sauce to keep it mild for the hubby. It was tasty but I think next time I would reduce the fish sauce just a bit and add a bit more soy sauce and garlic for a bit more flavor since I have to omit the chili/garlic sauce. Lastly, I did soak my noodle in hot water to speed up the soaking time. It was very good! Thank.

Excellent, I like a lot of sauce, so I doubled the sauce, substituted broccoli slaw for bean sprouts (which I can't get here). It was a tad salty, I may cut a little fish sauce next time, but overall simply excellent, my husband raved! I used a lot of crushed peanuts and cilantro.

This recipe is easy and delicious. I made half of the recipe because hubs doesn't like pad thai at all, but I was craving it. It made enough for dinner last night and lunch today. My only complaint with this recipe is that it seems a little heavy on the fish sauce. The flavor is good, but it's overwhelming as far as the smell goes, and that's a bit distracting. I had replaced a bit of the lime juice for tamarind nectar (which is located with the cans of other nectars in the ethnic aisle of the grocery store, if you can't find paste), but I think I will keep playing with the ratios of tamarind nectar, lime juice and fish sauce to find the right balance. I couldn't decide whether to use sweet chili sauce or sriracha -- I went with sweet chili sauce, but may also play with the heat next time.

This is a great, flexible recipe. I didn't want to go to a specialty store to get the ingredients for the sauce, so for the fish oil, I used the oil from sardines (and added a chopped-up sardine for good measure), I used soy sauce instead of oyster sauce, and used lime juice from concentrate, and added a little bit of vinegar to give it more punch. I also skipped the bean sprouts and used carrots (cut like match sticks) and shredded cabbage. I cooked the chicken and garlic first, then took that out and cooked the veggies until they were done, then removed them to add the egg, then noodles, sauce, etc. I skipped the shrimp too...and even with all these changes the recipe turned out fantastic. It was better than any restaurant pad thai and my boyfriend loved it too.

This is my go-to recipe for Pad Thai although I've made a couple of minor adjustments. The noodles need to soak longer than 20 minutes or you will end up with chewy, stuck together noodles. I pour boiling water over them and let them set 30-40 minutes. I do not use white sugar. It does not help at all. Use 2 tbsp brown instead and if it's still too salty for you (the fish sauce is super salty) add more and maybe more oyster sauce. The recipe says to divide the chili paste but never says where to add it in after the 2 tbsp to the sauce. I like mine spicy so I add it all in to the sauce. Family love this one!
Delish

My husband judges a Thai restaurant by their Pad Thai recipe so I was hesitant to try this on him. However, he gave it a good review and I've made it a bunch of times. I am not a fan of chicken so I use shrimp and tofu and double the sauce. It's perfect for us. I adjust the heat for days my kids are eating it with us and they love it too.
This recipe was lacking a ton of flavor
Pretty good but it was missing something
We followed the recommendation to add the tamarind and cut down the lime juice and it was fabulous! Thanks for the suggestions and recipe. It's now one of our favorites
Awesome and easy to make!

Very good. We have moved to a town that does not have a Thai restaurant. This is a good substitution. I used half the spice but barely noticed the heat. I will decrease the lime and increase the pepper sauce next time I make this meal. Thanks.
Tasty!

This recipe IS really worth making! :)
I made as written, except with a few changes. First, I could not find oyster sauce, so I just omited that. Second, my bf does not like anything spicy, so I didn't add the chili sauce either (I just used spicy sauce on mine). Also, between going to two stores, they only had 3 packs of bean sprouts (8 oz. I think) and 2 looked bad, so I only bought one, but next time I will definitely add more. I did not add shrimp. I made as written, and it came out so good. My bf ate all his and said it was as good as a Thai restaurant! I will be making this again.
BEST EVER PAD THAI
This came out really well. We modified the recipe by double the amount of shrimp and not using chicken. We also did one with tofu that came out very well.

This was good. I didn't have oyster sauce, so I subbed some stir-fry sauce. I left the meat out and skipped the peanuts. I didn't cook the noodles quite long enough, but that was my own fault. We enjoyed this- I served it with some eggrolls and it made for a great dinner. Thanks for sharing!

This is the best Pad Thai recipe I've ever tasted! I didn't have shrimp so just used chicken and added a bit of tamarind paste, other then that followed recipe to the tee! I now make a double batch cause there's never any leftovers!
Best pad thai recipe I've tried making - but definitely needs more kick. I tripled the amount of chile sauce and substituted hoisin sauce for oyster sauce since I didn't have any - turned out great!

A great Pad Thai recipe. I cut the fish sauce / oyster sauce in half, omit the shrimp (my wife doesn't like them) and add a little extra lime (since we really like that). Next time I make it I'll try the extra tamarind--that sounds good too.
This is pretty tasty...I used shrimp and tofu (instead of chicken). No other changes. Pretty easy and straightforward recipe.

My husband is Thai and this was not at all like the Pad Thai my mother in law makes. This was way too salty. I will try to make again with some modifications. Probably less fish sauce and just water instead of chicken stock. Will re-rate in the future with modified recipe.
Tastes like Thailand! I took the advice from earlier comments and added Tamarind sauce to the recipe and even taught my friends in Switzerland who missed some great Asian food!
Delish!
While this turned out to be a tasty dish, it did not have the true pad thai flavor that I craved.

Early warning.. This is one of those reviews where I didn't exactly follow the recipe. Rating it high anyway. Myself, my wife, and my daughter all LOVED it. There were a couple of servings left over but by the way my daughter acted, it won't be around for long. I used chicken bullion instead of stock and I completely cut the shrimp, fish stock, oyster sauce, and bean sprouts. But only because I couldn't find them at any of the local grocery stores. I will definitely make this again. Might add the shrimp next time, but the meal was substantial without it. . . .oh, and my wife and daughter both added a little bit more of the chili sauce to their servings. I didn't think it needed it.
I agree with the other reviews that it seemed like something was missing, but still very good. Nice and tangy!

This is the best Pad Thai I have ever eaten. Authentic, wonderful. I did, however, add Hoisen Sauce as suggested by reviewer (1tbl). Also, I doubled the eggs & omitted the chicken & fish. This makes it a really quick a easy dish & still has a lot of protein. Thank you for sharing your recipe! :)

I did not care for this recipe. I'm not a professional cook by any means, but I can hold my own, and it was so BLAND. I don't know if I did something wrong or not but I followed the recipe to the letter. I've never written a review before but felt I had to this time to let other people know, don't make this or kick it up quite a few notches if you do!

Made it with the suggestion of tamarind. Followed it nearly to the recipe except for using about 2 tablespoons of tamarind concentrate, 3 red thai chiles in addition to the sambal chili pepper sauce, and forgot to add the sugar. Added an extra egg, and used homemade chicken stock. I will def make again, and probably add tofu. Oh, you also don't have to measure the oil, just add enough to coat - it will not turn out greasy and will not be missed. Oh, I also found fresh rice noodles and so I just soaked them for about 5 min instead of 20. Perfection!

This was pretty simple to make and delicious. I cut the amount of chile pepper sauce in half (I have younger kids). They both liked it. I will be making this again, but I think I will use a little less oil.
AMAZING........
Good flavor, but very expensive considering the amount and prices of the multiple condiments. More cost effective in a restaurant, but a successful base recipe.

Delicious! I did add some more oyster, lime and fish sauce as I found it a bit bland. I also used tofu instead of chicken. I will definitely use this recipe again. Fast, easy, healthy and hubby loved it!
Very good Thanks Iris Lady

VERY tasty. If you don't have a wok, use big good quality dutch oven, otherewise you just end up steaming it all in their own juices. Next time I will increase the heat, double the sauce, and add chicken.
Perfect! Quick, easy and So yummy.

sorry, not recommended. I have concluded you have to be Thai to cook this dish. 1st it is not sweet, 2nd not very spicy (and according to the recipe you add to taste but the whole point is to cook it in for flavor thoroughness) , 3rd the sauce basically evaporates (it is not saucy). It is edible though so not a waste.
Very very good, but it needed a little something. I'll try adding tamarind apste next time, and there definitely will be a next time!!

This was absolutely wonderful. Here were my modifications: 1T Tamarind paste instead of fish sauce. 1/2 of the lime juice, Tamari sauce instead of oyster sauce, added thinly sliced carrots, and doubled the sauce. I also boiled the noodles first, instead of the soaking method which can make rice noodles gummy. Will definately make this again.

It tasted a little too fishy. I wish I would of read the reviews before I made this, I would of added the tamarind. I probably wouldn't have used all that fish sauce either. But it is a good recipe to start with.
This was really good. Gave it four stars because there needs to be more sauce in the recipe. Next time I will be doubling or tripling the sauce.
I made this for my mom on Mother's Day and she loved it. It was very simple to make. I just added a little bit more sugar than suggested.
I made this and I thought it was OK. Except it was SUPER salty. I did as some others suggested and doubled the sauce but I didn't add any extra anything.

Delicious! This was my first time making phad thai, and I was pleased. I took the suggestion of another reviewer and added tamarind paste (1 T). I also omitted the oyster sauce (didn't have it) and the shrimp (don't like it). Next time I will add a little more sugar to counteract the tartness of the tamarind. Oh, I also reduced the chili sauce just a bit as I am a bit wimpy with spice. With these changes, the recipe is nearly perfect. Four stars for an excellent recipe as written.
I still needed to add ketchup and I wanted more spice rather than heat so I will add ginger next time. But a great recipe!
Yummy Yummy Yummy

Tons of flavor in this dish. I thought too much of it came from the fish sauce though. It was too strong for me. I had to double the chicken because I didn't have shrimp. This dish was fun to cook, but again the fish sauce was too strong for me.

Ok I have now made this like a gazillion times. It is totally awesome. The only changes I made were to add tamarind paste and to double the sauce. Oh I also put in peanut butter. Everyone who has it wants more and the recipe.

This recipe is awesome. I followed it quite closely (my mistake buying lo mein noodles by accident) we cut back on the chile sauce for the sake of the kids. My teenager called it an "epic win". Need I say more?
it was definitely a pad thai worth making!
If I could give this a 0 I would! I did not care for this. I don't know if I prepared it wrong or what happened but it was not good.
This is tasty though not as good as the Pad Thai from restaurants and it's also on the salty side; you might want to try reduced-sodium chicken broth and soy sauce.

I usually just run out to the Thai Restaurant when I need my chicken Pad Thai fix, this was my first time actually making it at home and I have to say I was pleased with the results. I didn't add the oyster sauce, peanuts or the shrimp, I did add an additional 8oz of diced chicken and cayenne pepper for spice and it turned out great, Will keep this recipe to try again.
Pretty good, but quite bland. It was more like a regular stirfry.
